segments.text: California at San Diego a good idea for Scripps Institution?
I guess my opinion about that has had a lot of ups and downs.
I think in the long run, yes.
It was, well, perhaps one shouldn't say good or bad.
It was sort of inevitable.
The Scripps Institution was part of the University of California, and as long as it is to remain a part of the university, it would have been silly, I think, to consider
establishing a part of the university here in San Diego and not having it be tightly coordinated with Scripps.
As it turned out, I think that the existence of Scripps made it possible for us to build a very strong science faculty quite rapidly.
The other parts of the University of California, the new campuses of that same era,
have not achieved anything like the scientific eminence that the San Diego campus has.
We're right up there pushing along with Berkeley and Los Angeles, in spite of the fact that we're only about a third as big.
And I think in large measure this was due to Revell as an individual, but also due to the kind of high grade science community that we had here in the specialized realm of the ocean.
And a number of well-recognized people like Eckhart obviously made it easier to recruit good physicists to come.
They thought, you know, it was no sin to go to San Diego to work with Carl Eckhart and survive.
And so I think that was a big help.
As director and then, well, primarily as director at Scripps Institution of Motionography,

and your responsibility in terms of recruiting students and recruiting faculty members, did you feel as if the prestige of the institution allowed you to have sort of a choice of the upper echelon of science and students?
I think in the case of students, for a very long time, Scripps Institution was the place.
If you wanted to do graduate work in oceanography,
there was no question that it was the outstanding place to go.
As the world has developed, other places have grown too, and I think that the other two places that really compete strongly with us now are the MIT Woods Hole Complex and the Columbia University.
Those are the other two that we battle with occasionally these days for the best of the incoming students.
In terms of recruiting staff, that's again a kind of a place in which we do not have too much trouble.
Again, we do indeed compete primarily with MIT and Columbia.
particularly the MIT group in geology, geophysics, geophysics side of the world particularly.
They provided some fairly formidable competition.
You were asking about whether the development of the university or the full-scale campus here was something that I thought was good or bad.
It had a very interesting effect on the Scripps Institution in this period in which I
had to sit in the director's seat, because that was a period of some really deep soul-searching on the part of a lot of people in the Scripps Institution.
As the new people arrived in science, there was a very strong sort of centrifugal effect that all of a sudden here were eminent chemists, eminent physicists, and so forth.
And if you looked around, you could see the physicists and the chemists in the institution

beginning to think less about the ocean and about working together to solve the ocean's problems than about what kind of interaction they were having with the physicists or with the chemists, the people in their own disciplines.
Because we've been living in a kind of vacuum with regard to that for many years.
And so there was a strong centrifugal effect.
And I felt the main thing that I really had to work at while I was
director was the business of just keeping the institutions from flying apart.

Gradually this wore off and we went through a completely different stage some several years later in which the problems of general education and things like this, people who had had the luxury in earlier times of being able to specialize in
not have to interact with too big a group, and all that sort of thing.
These problems began to overwhelm people, and there was a great rush back toward the Scripps Institution in the late 60s.
In fact, there were people on the upper campus, as we call it, the general campus, who wanted to join the rush.
And there was a department, a whole department, the earth sciences department, which had been built within
the first college up on the UCSD general campus.
The science department staffed about half with Scripps people, and the other half with new recruits from various distinguished places.
And that department just claimed completely COVID, and all of the people
dashed back to the Scripps Institution because their interests were with really doing oceanographic research.
And I guess this is the place that underscores the fact that Scripps is a sort of anomalous place in the University of California.
It's a research institution with graduate educational responsibilities and public service responsibilities.
This is a very, there is another part of the University of California that is built like this.

And this means that we really are forever, every time there's a change in administration, a new chancellor on this campus or a new president of a statewide organization, we spend some fair amount of time having to go through indoctrination kinds of things to remind these people that this is, that the Scripps Institution part is not your conventional, it's neither a conventional university research institute, nor is it a conventional university department.
and it sort of sits in between these.
It's far more a research organization and, however, it's also a public service organization.
And the University of California, in the basic documentation that talks about what is the mission and the goal and so on, and what kinds of contributions do they expect faculty members to make,
The three things that are brought forward are teaching, research, and public service.
This third item is much more of a factor, I think, in a state university than in a place like Harvard, and really dates back to the days of the agricultural impact and all that sort of thing.
But Scripps Institution has much more of the flavor of this public service plan than other parts of the university.

and, in fact, is in major part, as far as university support, is funded out of the same budget as the budget that supports much of the agricultural research and so forth, the organized research budget, so-called, of the university as opposed to the instruction budget.
When you become chairman of the Oceanography Department,
Does that really change your role at all in Scripps Institution?
Yeah, yeah.
Well, I was chairman of the Oceanography Department back in 1963 or 4.
I gave, I passed that along to somebody else when I went back to being director of Scripps again.
In the interim between, in the late 60s, that department was reorganized, combined with

the marine biology curriculum that we'd had, and this previously existing earth sciences department, and we established a thing that we decided we would call the Graduate Department of the Scripps Institution of Oceanography, which essentially is an organizational entity that looks out for the students in a sort of formalistic way.
The students, since these are all graduate students and nearly all PhD type,
the students have to become involved in research.
And that involvement has to work through the research administering subdivisions of the institution.
The laboratories like the Marine Physical Laboratory, the research divisions, that sort of thing.
But what we had found out in the early 60s was that if we didn't have somebody who was charged with seeing that the students in fact had some financial support,
and that they, in fact, moved fruitfully toward finishing their degrees as opposed to getting research done.
Those are two rather different things.
That we would have students who were around for eight or ten years, and as oceanography became more widely known in the 60s, the number of applicants went up, and it became clear that, you know,
there was no way you could take in numbers of people who were applying and expect them all to stay around for six or eight years.
In fact, there was no reason for them to stay around that long.
So we established this departmental structure, which then sees that students take their qualifying examinations at reasonable times and
the committees are properly appointed and things of that sort.
And essentially I took over the responsibility of the chairmanship of that department just this last January, so I'm doing essentially a second tour as department chairman.
It does change your role because it means that, or it adds to your role I suppose, because I didn't drop any responsibilities when I took on this one, in that you have to

think about the role of the institution in a different way, in terms of what kind of a contribution it's making specifically to the students, as opposed to what kind of contribution it's making to Oceania.
Now, when your scientific liaison officer for Western Europe, what does that mean?
That was an interesting interview.
The Office of Naval Research
has been overall a very enlightened organization.
It really started out right after World War II as the only really effective supporter of research in the United States.
And that role is no longer its role anymore.
The National Science Foundation has grown in strength and purpose and capability.

But one of the things that the Office of Naval Research did, starting right after World War II, was it established an office in London whose initial goal was to help scientists on the European continent to get back in action after World War II.
And it was pretty successful in doing this, partly by providing communication and liaison, finding out where people were, providing some monetary support.

equipment and things of this kind that went on for several years and then of course the scientific community in europe became its own community again and but the navy decided that it would be useful to maintain for the benefit really of the entire u.s scientific community some kind of liaison with the european community so that this london office stayed in existence staffed by people who are
scientists on leave from various universities or government laboratories, whatever the typical duration of tour might be.
Well, we'd like them to be two years or something like that.
In recent times, it's been difficult to get people to go for that long.
When you go over there, the aim of the game is, in fact, to make contact with as many people as you can throughout Europe and in whatever your field may be.
go visit them, learn about what they're doing, but also to help them to find out what's going on in the United States.
So it's sort of a two-way street, and you don't go out visiting without providing something in return.

Make a seminar of your own while you're there, or a great deal of helping people to be in touch with particularly the sort of gray literature that most of the scientists in Europe are just as good as we are about reading and reading

publications, but they don't always have access to reports that are done within ONR contracts or NASA contracts or something like that, which sometimes have very useful information in them, but which are not always easily accessible to people in the European community.

And so one of the ways that you can help people over there is to put them in touch with that sort of thing, with other people in the United States who are working on things that seem to be similar to theirs.
And I went over there in the summer of 74 and came back in the fall of 75.
In my case it was particularly nice because it was a chance to expand a little bit on my areas of interest.

I was the only person on the staff for most of that grade, either in acoustics or in oceanography, which meant that I could go around and see what was going on in acoustics and diagnosis in hospitals and things like this, or go out and see what was going on in fisheries research and things that I have a marginal interest in but don't always have much time to keep track of when I'm involved here.
The Conrad Award for Contribution to the Navy Science Program in 74.
For what was that given?
Good behavior.
That's an award that is handed out by the Navy to people who played a role, not necessarily as individual research people, but in
management was not really quite the right word either.
Pulling together, stimulating, seeing that the research goes forward in a fruitful way, in a way that's fruitful to the Navy.

And it's an award that over the years has been given to directors of Navy laboratories on occasion, directors of research groups, an occasional admiral during there who's run a major program or made major contributions to research activity.
his vibratory and physical vibratory had been successful enough within the, oh, in honor of context, over the years that eventually it got to be enough, but I decided to give him that.
Oh, what about the award from the Franklin Institute in 1965?
That was a different kind of thing.
It was really related to Flip, which is a vehicle that I had.
bringing into reality.
It was recognition for, well, it's like a lot of other medals.
It's hard in science these days to give a medal to a person, because in general, you don't do anything alone.
And in fact, in this particular instance, I guess the main thing I can say is that I raised the money, and did some of the design calculations, and
I guess I wasn't the only doer by any means, but I suppose I was the leader in getting it done.
He worked in the laboratory.
That was a craft that was a lot of fun to do and has been an important tool for carrying out quite a wide range of research things and it grew out of a Navy program which

was a part and you could see that there was a role that our laboratory could play and we sort of visualized this craft to take out to sea and well I mentioned the fact that we used to go to sea in submarines to hold hydrophones nice and still well once we got a flip we stopped going to sea in submarines because we could hang the hydrophones nice and still in the water and there wouldn't be about
half a dozen of us out there scientists and even half a dozen crewmen instead of half a dozen scientists and 80 to 100 crewmen, which you generally have in an ordinary military submarine.
So it was really a pretty good sort of thing.
What exactly was the elevation?
Well, it was, the idea was to provide a platform which would sit stably in the ocean and
We were initially studying a thing that's kind of like the twinkling of stars, namely the fluctuations in apparent direction of a variety of sound as it's transmitted through the water.
And so what we wanted was a place where we could mount hydrophones down well within the water column, in this case down inside 300 feet, which is as far as the bottom of the cliff.
And then one could go off in the distance and hang a sound source down from a ship
And you could sight from up at the top out in the air, you could sight off to where the sound source was.
At the same time you could determine the direction of the arrival of the sound and how that direction fluctuated back and forth because of the smaller temperature differences within the ocean.
And so it gave us this kind of a rigid structure and as with other things we've done, the idea was to see
if we could put something together that would solve one problem but would be flexible enough that it could solve a bunch of other problems later on that we only vaguely have a sense of.
And in fact, it's been pretty successful in that regard.
It's a good thing for hanging things down quietly.
Now, it's been suggested at least that Dr.
The 60s were in effect, particularly the middle to late 60s, were sort of an age of invention which brought together all kinds of techniques to sending oceanographers out to sea.
This may be over, that oceanography may now revert to having more and more work done in the lab and a systematic work with the data already produced.
Would you agree with this?
To some extent this has to be true.
Partly because communication has become so much better and we've developed or are in the process of developing ways of looking at some aspects of the ocean anyway.
Using things like satellites for example where it really
you might just as well be sitting in your lab as any place else.
It doesn't mean you're going to get to be on a ship if you're going to use satellite data.
It's going to come pouring down out of the sky by whatever radio link it uses.
And you're going to sit at home near your computer and try to understand what that information means.
I think, on the other hand, there is much, in some ways, there is less
working in the data manipulation business after an operation is over.
It used to be that you'd go out and make some measurements and you had to come home and work those over very, very heavily before you could write a paper.

ability to take computers to sea with us, and to take more sophisticated instruments for doing chemical analyses, and whatever, also, has meant that the turnaround time for a problem of a given level of complexity is going to be a lot shorter.
So you have these two things kind of working against one another when you try to guess what the oceanographer of the future is going to do as far as going to sea.
On the one hand, he has the capability to go to sea
and get his data in shape to draw some conclusions a lot faster than he could before.
So his turnaround time to get ready to go back out to sea and find something else has increased.

In fact, almost the limiting factor there is the publication time or something of this kind, because the granting agencies like to see something in hard print before they like to keep on funding you to go on off for the next trip.
And yet the early part of the data analysis can go very, very fast.

So if there's that working against the fact that there are other buoys, satellites, and things of this kind that make it possible to do perfectly good oceanography without ever running out of our ship at all.
Okay.
What particular problems in the immediate future do you see oceanography addressing itself to?
I don't know.
There's two kinds of problems.
scientific problems.
And here I guess the air-sea interaction problem is a major one that is attracting a lot of attention and is going to require a lot more attention before it really is solved.
Biological
questions still remain kind of elusive in terms of what we can do about them.
Geology, geophysics part has benefited greatly from improved instrumentation, ability to make measurements that are relevant.
in quite a variety of ways.
And the geologists who 10 or 15 years ago played just qualitative games and looked at rocks and things like this now know as much geophysics as geophysicists do in many instances.
And it's hard to draw the line.
And they've learned to work with sophisticated instrumentation and draw conclusions from this in conjunction with whatever things you do with actual samples.

the biologists haven't gotten quite around to this place yet partly because it's not as easy to solve their problems with the instrumentation side of the game because at least you know where the sea floor is and it's likely to stay there it's only going to move a few centimeters per year or something of this kind whereas the biological situation will change very rapidly it changes
and rapidly in both space and time.

The question of patchiness of distribution of animals in the sea, plants and animals, why this occurs, what kinds of scales, and how much of this is behavioral, how much of it is hydrodynamic, things of this kind.
These are all the questions that I think remain to be answered.
There is a question in sort of sociological terms, I suppose, as to who wants to know about the ocean anyway, sort of, you know?
The biological situation often is justified in
people's minds by fisheries-type activities.
Really, and that's a perfectly good justification in its own way.
The question of what level of research activity you can justify, however, is a different one.
And this is why I think that some other aspects

than the fisheries are beginning to drive the biological situation in the sense that people would like to know if you spill a bunch of oil out of a ship, what's that going to do to the biological situation in the sea?
A supertanker full of oil represents as much money as an awful lot of fishing.
And so, although the
the destruction of life in the sea or something like that is approached on a sort of aesthetic basis almost.
The question of whether people are going to exact retribution from oil tanker drivers
who do pollute the ocean.
If they are, then there has to be a lot more argument about marine biology involved in all that.
So the tanker drivers and oil companies are going to claim that, in fact, you know, I haven't been in the ocean anyway.
And the amounts of money that are going to be involved between governments trying to just maintain those...
the nice values of life.
You may all get involved in more money than you didn't think of in the fisheries business.
And finally, where do you think your career is going to go?
I don't know.
I have a couple of, some research things that I hope I'll be able to work on.
seem to me to be interesting whether I can convince other people that they're interesting enough to fund them.
That's another kind of thing I'd like to do.
So I'm very careful measuring the displacement of the floor of the ocean.
The plate tectonics model that has come out of recent geology and geophysics certainly says that the pieces of the crust of the earth are sliding around
people are beginning to be able to measure these motions directly on land, like on the San Andreas Fault, or in Iceland, when the spreading centers come up to the sea surface.
And I'd like to go ahead and make some measurements of this kind on the deep sea floor, spreading centers.
This, I think, is within the realm of technology.

Also, I'm getting to a place where I probably have to think rather more about looking perhaps at a broader picture, and I've tried to look at a broader picture for a long time, but I think the question of interactions outside of the sphere of just this laboratory and this institution
There are numerous opportunities and other kinds of things in that area.
Perhaps that will happen.
